candidates.title: fix(deps): Fix openssl dependency chaos and test failure (#51)
candidates.body: This builds without problems on my host, FWIW.

candidates.title: fix(openssl): Update to 0.9.x
candidates.body:
Hey so I tried to use this on MacOS and ran into the typical rust openssl include error.
This was fixed in openssl 0.9.4.
I figured updating yup-oauth2 would help others that run into a similar issue.

candidates.title: Use docs.rs for documentation
candidates.body:
@Byron Let me know if I forgot something; I grepped for locations pointing to the old documentation, but I think I got everything (but it's your setup, so you know it better :)

I'll add a redirect page to `gh-pages` afterwards, so nobody is confused by stale documentation.

candidates.title: docs(links): link from byron/ to dermesser/
candidates.body:
The only link not working just yet is coveralls, which
apparently needs a login by the owner and minor configuration
to work (e.g. webhooks).

Also please note that the Cargo.toml has changed to fix the
documentation link. It would need a re-publish to fix it appears.

candidates.title: fix(serde): use serde_derive
candidates.body:
serde_macros is no longer maintained and will eventually
fail on nightly.
Also in a hopefully not-so-distant future, we will be able
to use macros 1.1 in stable, and thus get rid of the
complication required for the hybrid approach.

candidates.title: Bump version to 1.0.0
candidates.body:
Fixes #33.

Please publish to crates.io, if there's nothing blocking anymore! :-)

candidates.title: fix(example): Use crates.io version of google-pubsub1 for examples
candidates.body: This was a local change that leaked into a commit.

candidates.title: fix(deps): Use small base64 crate instead of rustc-serialize
fix(deps): Pin dependencies to specific (major) versions
Add service account example
candidates.body: (I'm still creating PRs so you know what's going on -- otherwise I can just push directly)

candidates.title: Implement the service account "flow"
candidates.body:
Sorry for the delay, I finally got around to doing it :)

tl;dr: The service account flow doesn't really fit the Authenticator model (because it's non-interactive), so I made it a distinct implementation of `GetToken`.

I also initially planned on using the `jwt` crate. However, that crate sends a JWT header of `{"type": "RSS256", "typ": "JWT", "kid": null}`, and the last `kid` property causes the OAuth frontend to return a `500`. I fell back to implementing the functionality myself, i.e. signing the message using OpenSSL (as it turns out, I had to use OpenSSL anyways in order to parse the key for `jwt` to sign the message...).

There's also the `frank_jwt` crate, but looking through it I wasn't sure whether it'd work smoothly with the picky Google frontend.

Let me know what you think!

candidates.title: fix(dependencies): use url = 0.5; the bump to 1.0 broke us
feat(flows): Implement flow for installed apps
candidates.body:
_Now_ I got it :-)

The "Installed App Flow" requires user interaction; we first generate a
URL that the user has to navigate to. Then, the user either pastes a
displayed code into the app being authorized, or the OAuth provider
redirects the user's browser to a webserver that is running on
localhost. This webserver is provided by the library and the flow should
work automatically. Extensive documentation can be found here:
https://developers.google.com/identity/protocols/OAuth2InstalledApp
An example for the InstalledFlow with the Drive API is here:
https://gist.github.com/dermesser/8c915ec4c88ee8e8927e7d40b276ca52

candidates.title: feat(storage): Implement DiskTokenStorage
candidates.body:
DiskTokenStorage is a TokenStorage that stores its tokens in a JSON file
on disk. That file can be read in later, and the tokens in it reused.
(The idea for using a cache file is from here:
 https://developers.google.com/drive/v3/web/quickstart/go#step_3_set_up_the_sample)
